title: "It’s possible to earn 4 keys (12 fragments) in a 4 week period" - Riot
body:
Tell that to the 6 chests sitting in my inventory next to 2 key fragments.

Exactly how many games does Riot expect us to play to get to that level? I already play more than I should.

I generally try to do off-meta or otherwise weird champions for chests early on where possible, with the intent to switch to more meta picks when I'm close to having a second chest available. I've never actually gotten close to having two chests available to earn though, if you spam any champ enough you eventually have stompy games.

I feel like I manage 3 and a bit keys rather than the full 4 though, which makes me slowly fall behind, with me sitting on 5 chests currently and no frags. That I can't even catch up unless I mess up my S chest earning is somewhat frustrating.

You can get chests off alternate game modes. I got mine for kassadin on blood moon (a champion I would NEVER have gotten one on otherwise). Nobody plays him this mode despite being really good (albeit UN intuitive). Last week it was dunking people with flash bear Annie for an S+, and then seeing her win rate on the mode be 47% and being like... It's Annie, how are y'all fcking this up?

This. If you game the rules S becomes absurdly easy. And there are a surprising number of champions that just get it really easily. Rammus jungle can almost feed and still get s-

If you spam any champ enough, you might just get reported enough to get banned though. This happened to support singed a while back and even ADC teemos. You can't do this because it makes people toxic, which according to riot makes you toxic and then you get banned.

As long as you are trying to win, and communicating with your team (and especially in normals), then you won't get in trouble or be banned. Occasionally teammates might get a bit toxic, but if you don't respond in kind (or y'know, at all) then you're fine. 

If things are super janky and not just sorta not ideal but ok I guess, then maybe run it by your team in champ select first. Theres a lot of 'off-meta' or weird picks that are still fine, but they're just not top 5 in the current meta and hence off-meta. For example I've been doing a fair bit of kayle support recently, which is somewhat off-meta, but she is/was a popular support pick once upon a time, she's just somewhat outclassed in the role these days, so most people don't care. If I were to try to do something like master yi support on the other hand, that might not go over so well.

I'm not saying to shove champions in a specific role ({{champion:164}} support or {{champion:40}} top/mid).

I'm saying that if you play something like {{champion:60}} support or something that could work in a specific role but doesn't secure a win then you are more likely to get reported when it goes wrong.

Which is fine, since getting reported has almost nothing to do with getting punished. Reports are reviewed (generally by automated stuff first, then by rioters), and if you were doing your best to make it work and communicating properly, then it wouldn't matter if everyone reported you. Reports just flag things for review, and if people got banned for getting reported then there probably wouldn't be very many players left (including rioters who you can be pretty confident are behaving themselves).
It's not that hard in normals, you can get s with non-meta picks if you know what you are doing.
Not saying it's hard. Just saying that if you don't play well, you get flamed by team mates and blamed for the loss. Not something I want to do.

It's honestly not that hard; just farm a lot and don't die. You don't even have to win. The mistake people make is thinking they have to actually contribute to their team's chances of winning to get an S
Well, generally speaking, kills and assists tend to mean a lot in ranking. If you end a game going 0/3/20 with 160 CS, you are less likely to get an S than someone who goes 4/1/17 with 100 CS

The percentage chance to get a key fragment goes down after each one you get, but gets reset each month.  Playing in a premade raises your chances to get a key fragment(I have no idea why they choose to do this).   At the beginning of the reset you have an 80% chance for the first one down to about 7% chance for the 12th one(if you are playing alone).   So playing alone it will take you about **84 WINS** to get 12 key fragments on average.  With a 50% win rate that is 168 games over a month or about 5.6 games a day.   So yeah that is a lot. 

If you played only in 5 man premades you could get that down to an average of 76 wins.
Where did you get the percent rates? Just wondering if a Rioter posted it.

It was posted on reddit.  But not by a Rioter, I can't remember how they said they got it.  Plus it was from back in April so honestly they might have changed it some what since then.   The formula was (.8 + 0.02x)/y  where x=number of people you are premade with and y is number key fragments you have gotten since the reset.  So if you are solo, first win has an 80% chance as does the second then it goes down to 40%.
Riots technically telling the truth. You can get that many keys in that time period. However, you have to play a TON for that to happen. I had a month where that happened to me.

Actually I recorded my key drop rates for about 7 months last year when I played.

It can take anywhere from just 36 **wins** to 58+ to get all 12. I played mostly solo.

If you play aram more the drop rate can be very very bad after the first 6. The first six fragments are usually gotten by 10-18 wins. One time I went 16 **wins** when I was supposed to get a key drop, without getting one. I was actually expecting the rng failsafe to be more generous. It was only the 9th ish key too.

So yeah the drop rate is baaaad if you want 3 to 4 boxes a month.
